text: ...and nothing on immigration. Is it any wonder nobody trusts the media anymore?
One key takeaway...NBC's Lester Holt gave us a birther question, a Trump tax return question, only 20 seconds on Hillary's emails...
15 minutes left...anyone else interested in an immigration question?
It's a problem that won't be fixed until we have school choice.
Hillary is wrong: race does NOT determine where you go to school. The government does. They control the monopoly on education.

Maybe Hillary needs to come see Lancaster County. And Chester. And Fairfield before she defends NAFTA.

I suppose the takeaway here is pretty clear: just as some banks were too big to fail, some people in our society are just too big to jail.
And apparently you can get caught in those lies, and 50% of the country still thinks you'd be a super President.
And that's not me saying that. That is the FBI. The same one that said they had no evidence of any malicious intent.
"My private email system was secure." FALSE.
"The emails were not classified." FALSE. "I returned all the e-mails." FALSE. "The emails were not marked classified." FALSE.
It's hard to know where the list of Secretary Clinton's lies on this topic end:
I suppose he was deciding who gets one treatment under the law, and who gets different treatment.
..“To the contrary, those individuals are often subject to security or administrative sanctions. But that is not what we are deciding now.”
“To be clear, this is not to suggest that in similar circumstances, a person who engaged in this activity would face no consequences.”
I wonder what the FBI Director meant when he said this:
Maybe David Petraeus should have invoked the "I didn't mean to do it" defense.
I wonder what David Petraeus would say to all that. In fact, do you remember the "no malicious intent" angle being applied to the General?
(as apparently the FBI "cannot rule out" that the information was accessed surreptitiously by foreign actors.)
-& this is the part that should scare everyone to death-be so careless w' confidential info that our enemies could gain access to it..
Apparently, today, it is no longer against the law to destroy public records, evade valid freedom of information act strictures, or...
(it was OK to lie in court about extramarital affairs) ...might turn a federal felony into just "little white lies."
I remember thinking to myself then that perjury was no longer a crime or at least the subject matter of the perjury
...but that "everyone did it."
I remember back in the 90s as I watched in disbelief as the POTUS-when accused of perjury in federal court-admit that he'd lied...
I hear all of this psychobabble about "lack of malicious intent," but our jails are full of people who "didn't mean to do it."
The FBI decision today is outrageous. If I had done what Mrs. Clinton had done, I would be in jail. Period. So would you.
Anyway, to the extent that I have earned a reputation for being even-keeled, I am going to do my best to destroy that reputation right now:
I like to think that I tend not to participate in the most hyperbolic of political discourse.
I'm back up in DC today and I apologize for being slow to comment on the FBI decision today not to prosecute Hillary Clinton.

At this point, we have a good bit of information and it's clear this was an act of terrorism.
My thoughts & prayers are with the first responders and law enforcement officials who put their lives at risk when they ran into the chaos.
My thoughts & prayers are with the innocent victims and their families.
I watched along with the rest of you yesterday as details emerged about the terrorist attack in Orlando.
My response to that line of reasoning has been fairly simple: "Well, only if we vote for a bailout." Which I won't, for one.
Some in GOP suggest that if the bill didn't pass, then there would somehow inevitably be a "real" bailout in the future.
Bottom line=no bailout, but there's a risk that you and I might end up paying more when we borrow $ for schools/roads or save for retirement
It would also make it more expensive for people to invest in municipal bonds-something that is in large part done by retirees in my district
...that bond market will respond by raising borrowing costs on other municipal debt, including that in South Carolina.
That's b'c there is a real risk that, if the pension payments are moved up in line so that they get paid before the debts of the island...
And believe it or not, it is a big deal FOR YOU, not just the folks in Puerto Rico.
At the same time, I could never get comfortable on the second ?. The issue of the elevation of the pension payments is a really big deal.
There was no bailout. No taxpayer money changes hands as part of this bill. Period.  #PuertoRico
For me to vote for the bill, the answer to both of those questions had to be a solid "no." #PuertoRico
1)Was there a taxpayer bailout? & 2)Did passing the bill create a risk that future pension payments would be "elevated" above debt payments?
For me, there were 2 critical issues. #PuertoRico
The Puerto Rico bill passed the House last night. The final vote was 297-197, with 139 R's and 158 D's voting for. I voted against it.

It’s almost as if he just decided to stop because he had a big applause line there at the end.    

Well, let’s leave it at that then.
This was pretty much the same old, same old.  Kind of strange if you ask me.
Wait, that’s it?  Well, I guess the rumors about some dramatic revelations were overblown.
But I fail to see how asking someone to show a photo ID when he/she votes makes it harder for him/her to vote.
I agree with the President that we should make it as easy as possible for people to vote….as long as they only vote once.
My fear is that that is exactly what he is talking about...
Unless, of course, “bipartisanship” to the President means that I just accept his way of seeing the world.
Because you are almost an hour into your speech so far, and you are sadly short on bipartisan ideas so far.
Why don’t you start out by telling us where you are willing to work with us.
Me, who represents 700,000 people in SC, or you, who represents 300,000,000?  I'm happy to work with you.
Let’s talk about bipartisanship.  Who do you think should lead on that, Mr. President?
Do you think he even sees any parallel between what he wants for Muslims and how he is actually treating Christians? #justsaying
He tells Christians that they have to abandon their principles in order to be right-thinking Americans.  Is that right?   Is it fair?
But hasn't the president done exactly that to devout Christians who object, on religious grounds, to abortion or gay marriage?
I agree that insulting people on the basis of their faith is wrong. #preach
BUT we just sent 10,000 bombing missions to get them.  Does that sound internally inconsistent to anyone other than me?
But at the same time, this is the sort of double-talk that drives me nuts:  the President just said that ISIS is not a threat to us…
We absolutely should put that to a vote:  indeed, it is our Constitutional duty to do so.
The president is absolutely correct on the Congressional authorization.
Ok…I’m on board with prioritizing going after terrorists.   Be curious to see how we wants to do that — and happy to work with him on that.
If George Bush had presided over that kind of decline, the mainstream media would have made it a nightly story for months at a time.
Fact:   American standing in the world is worse now than it was 7 years ago in every country in the world OTHER than Iran and Cuba.
I mean, if I said that kind of stuff people would think I was nuts. And they’d probably be right.
PLEASE tell me that someone at MSNBC/CNN/ABC are taking notes and going to press him on some of this stuff.
Wait…what?  Our enemies aren’t getting stronger?  Did he just say that?
@BresPolitico just calling it as I see it...
Nothing like giving an entirely partisan view on things, then attacking your opposition for not being bipartisan.
I can't wait to hear him get to the part about how he is going to make politics a kindler, gentler business.
In fact, if there is anything “different” it is that he is going even more overboard on the liberal talking points.
Because so far this sounds just like every other campaign speech he has ever given.
30 mins in -- and if the President was originally promising a different kind of speech, now would be a good time to start.
He has co-opted the CEOs of corporations from GE to Google-but somehow President Obama is for the little guy & Republicans are for fat cats?
But big corporations? He set a record for the amount of political money raised on Wall Street.
OK…the first place tonight I can agree with. Figuring out ways to help people up and out of poverty should be a priority.
I will remember that next month when I pay my premiums again — which are higher after I lost my healthcare plan (and my doctor).
So now the Affordable Care act is just a “gap-filler?”
& my guess is that we won’t hear much tonight about how he wants to pay for that.I suppose he’s happy to have his grandkids worry about that
Stunningly, college got MORE expensive once the federal government took over the college loan system.
A familiar liberal talking point: free college education.
I am really surprised at the extent to which he seems to be detached from reality so far.
$15 an hour minimum wage?  I seriously hope that the larger media world takes him to task on some of this stuff.
So the economy is better, but most people aren’t better off.  Again, he has been in office for 7 years.  What are his ideas to fix that?
The real question is:  why are we worse off in ALL FOUR of those areas after 7 years of his Presidency.
He asks four questions…how can we be better in various areas?
Go to a Trump rally. Go to a Sanders rally. Then tell me how wonderful everything is... #peopleareangry
Wow, this is going to be a long night, regardless of how short the speech is. I am really not sure if he been around the country recently.
Stronger and better?  In what sense?  Militarily? Economically? Culturally?  I’m not sure what country he has been living in.
Hmm…gun control, higher minimum wage…sounds like we can look forward to a liberal cavalcade of stars tonight
That would save us half an hour, easily...
In fact, I loved Rand Paul’s promise that, if he becomes President, he won’t allow any applause or standing during his SOTU speeches.
Well, I am all for a short speech.  And that is not a slam against the President.  I think ALL political speeches should be shorter.
Well…we are off to a bad start.  ALREADY 4 MINUTES LATE.  And we haven't even started all the standing-up yet...
